title: US History
subject: history-us
description: Explore key events and figures in American history

items.text: In 1607, [blank] became the first permanent English settlement in America.
items.explain: Jamestown, Virginia was established by the Virginia Company in 1607.

items.text: The [blank] arrived at Plymouth Rock in 1620.
items.explain: The Pilgrims sailed on the Mayflower and established Plymouth Colony.

items.text: The [blank] colonies were established by people seeking religious freedom.
items.explain: There were 13 British colonies along the Atlantic coast before independence.

items.text: The Revolutionary War started in [blank].
items.explain: The war began with battles at Lexington and Concord in April 1775.

items.text: [blank] was the commander of the Continental Army.
items.explain: Washington led the colonial forces to victory against Britain.

items.text: The Battle of [blank] was a major turning point in the war.
items.explain: The victory at Saratoga in 1777 convinced France to support the colonies.

items.text: The Declaration of Independence was signed on July 4, [blank].
items.explain: July 4, 1776 is celebrated as Independence Day in the United States.

items.text: [blank] wrote most of the Declaration of Independence.
items.explain: Thomas Jefferson drafted the document declaring independence from Britain.

items.text: The [blank] is the supreme law of the United States.
items.explain: The Constitution was written in 1787 and established our government.

items.text: [blank] was the first President of the United States.
items.explain: Washington served from 1789 to 1797 and set many presidential traditions.

items.text: [blank] was the third President and doubled the size of the US.
items.explain: Jefferson purchased the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803.

items.text: [blank] wrote the Federalist Papers supporting the Constitution.
items.explain: Hamilton, Madison, and Jay wrote essays explaining the Constitution.

items.text: The [blank] Purchase doubled the size of the United States.
items.explain: In 1803, the US bought the Louisiana Territory from France.

items.text: [blank] and Clark explored the western territories.
items.explain: Lewis and Clark's expedition (1804-1806) mapped the Louisiana Purchase.

items.text: The [blank] Trail was a major route for settlers moving west.
items.explain: Over 400,000 pioneers traveled the Oregon Trail in the 1840s-1860s.

items.text: The Civil War lasted from 1861 to [blank].
items.explain: The war ended when Confederate General Lee surrendered in April 1865.

items.text: [blank] was President during the Civil War.
items.explain: Lincoln led the Union and worked to end slavery during the war.

items.text: The [blank] Proclamation freed enslaved people in Confederate states.
items.explain: Lincoln issued this proclamation on January 1, 1863.

items.text: The [blank] Amendment abolished slavery in the United States.
items.explain: The 13th Amendment was ratified in December 1865.

items.text: The [blank] Amendment granted citizenship to former slaves.
items.explain: The 14th Amendment (1868) defined citizenship and equal protection.

items.text: The [blank] Amendment gave voting rights to African American men.
items.explain: The 15th Amendment (1870) prohibited denying votes based on race.

items.text: [blank] invented the light bulb and phonograph.
items.explain: Edison was a prolific inventor during the Industrial Revolution.

items.text: [blank] developed the assembly line for mass production.
items.explain: Ford's assembly line revolutionized manufacturing, especially for cars.

items.text: The [blank] connected the east and west coasts by rail in 1869.
items.explain: The railroad linked California to the eastern United States.

items.text: The US entered World War I in [blank].
items.explain: The US joined WWI in April 1917 on the side of the Allies.

items.text: The US entered World War II after the attack on [blank].
items.explain: Japan attacked Pearl Harbor, Hawaii on December 7, 1941.

items.text: [blank] was President during most of World War II.
items.explain: FDR led the US from 1933 until his death in April 1945.

items.text: [blank] led the Montgomery Bus Boycott in 1955.
items.explain: MLK Jr. emerged as a leader during this 381-day protest.

items.text: [blank] refused to give up her bus seat, sparking the boycott.
items.explain: Rosa Parks' act of civil disobedience in 1955 became a pivotal moment.

items.text: The [blank] Act of 1964 outlawed discrimination based on race.
items.explain: This landmark law prohibited discrimination in public places and employment.
